key_points: Hurricane Ida makes landfall in Louisiana as a Category 4 storm on the 16th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina.
Ida's maximum sustained winds were 150 mph at landfall, making it an 'extremely dangerous' hurricane.
Only two other hurricanes have made landfall in Louisiana with winds as strong: Last Island in 1856 and Hurricane Laura in 2020.
All flights to and from New Orleans airport were canceled, with hundreds of cancellations reported over the weekend.
Airport spokesperson Erin Burn announced preparations and cancellations due to Hurricane Ida.
Hurricane-force winds reached southeastern Louisiana on Sunday morning.
A NOAA station reported sustained winds of 105 mph and a gust of 121 mph.
Flash flood warnings issued in Louisiana with rainfall rates of up to 3 inches per hour expected.
Hurricane Katrina, which hit in 2005, is recalled amidst Ida's landfall.
New Orleans' vulnerability to hurricanes highlighted due to its elevation and lack of natural defenses.
